content: The "Maritime Security Coordination Improvement Act" requires the Secretary to submit updates on the strategic plan for enhancing international supply chain security every three years. Additionally, it includes provisions for the Container Security Initiative. SEC. 3. CONTAINER SECURITY INITIATIVE. Amends section 205 of the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 regarding timelines and redesignation of paragraphs. SEC. 4. CYBER AT PORTS. The text chunk discusses cybersecurity enhancements to maritime security activities, including the sharing of information on cybersecurity risks and incidents to address port-specific cybersecurity risks. It also mentions the establishment of a working group to address these risks. The text chunk amends sections related to cybersecurity in maritime security activities, including prevention, management, and response to cybersecurity risks and incidents. It aligns with the Homeland Security Act of 2002 definitions. SEC. 5 amends facility inspection intervals to verify security plans annually and as needed. SEC. 6 updates recognition of other countries' trusted shipper programs. SEC. 218 requires the Secretary to notify congressional committees before signing an arrangement with a foreign government for mutual recognition of supply chain security practices. The foreign government's program must provide comparable security as C-TPAT. SEC. 434. UPDATES OF MARITIME OPERATIONS COORDINATION PLAN. This section amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to include updates to the Maritime Operations Coordination Plan. The Secretary must submit a maritime operations coordination plan to specified committees every 180 days, updating the plan released in July 2011. The plan will focus on coordinating and integrating maritime operations for homeland security missions. The Secretary is responsible for maritime homeland security missions, including maintaining information sharing, cooperation with other agencies, and working within national maritime security guidance. A clerical amendment is made to the Homeland Security Act of 2002. SEC. 8. EVALUATION OF COAST GUARD DEPLOYABLE SPECIALIZED FORCES. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report to specified committees within one year of this Act's enactment, assessing the Coast Guard's Deployable Specialized Forces (DSF) including cost analysis, personnel numbers, and unit totals for the past three fiscal years. The report must include the total number of units and operations conducted by the Coast Guard's Deployable Specialized Forces (DSF) in the past three fiscal years. It should also detail the number of operations requested and fulfilled by various entities, as well as examine alternative distributions of DSFs for feasibility, cost, and impact on mission capability. The Deployable Specialized Force (DSF) of the Coast Guard is defined as a unit that handles counter-drug, counter-terrorism, and anti-terrorism operations. The DSFs are proposed to be centralized under one command for counterdrug operations and to have capabilities distributed to each major port for counter-terrorism efforts. SEC. 9. COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS OF CO-LOCATING DHS ASSETS. The Secretary of Homeland Security must conduct a cost-benefit analysis for co-locating aviation and maritime assets of the Office of Air and Marine Operations with other Department of Homeland Security agencies within 45 miles. Factors to consider include enhanced cooperation from co-location and potential savings from shared maintenance and logistics facilities. The Secretary of Homeland Security must conduct a cost-benefit analysis for co-locating aviation and maritime assets within 45 miles. Factors include joint use of infrastructure, operational costs, moving costs, and facility enlargement. A report summarizing the analysis results must be submitted to relevant committees within one year. The Senate must receive a report summarizing the results of the cost-benefit analysis and any planned actions based on the findings. SEC. 10 repeals sections 70107A and 70116 of title 46, United States Code. SEC. 11 includes conforming and clerical amendments. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended by redesignating and striking various sections. This includes redesignating sections 106 and 107 as sections 105 and 106, and redesignating sections 109 and 110 as sections 107 and 108. Additionally, subsections (c), (d), and (e) of section 121 are struck, and sections 122 and 127 are also struck. Sections 123, 124, 125, 126, and 128 are redesignated as sections 122, 123, 124, 125, and 126, respectively. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is further amended by striking and redesignating various sections, including sections 233, 235, 236, 701, and 708. The table of contents is also amended by removing items related to sections 105. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended by removing items related to sections 105 through 110 and inserting new items. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended by removing items related to sections 105 through 110 and inserting new items related to transportation security cards, long-range vessel tracking, notice of arrival for foreign vessels, and enhanced crewmember identification. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended to include new items such as random searches of containers, work stoppages resolution, threat assessment screening for port truck drivers, Border Patrol unit for US Virgin Islands, and Center of Excellence for Maritime Domain Awareness. Additionally, information sharing on supply chain security cooperation is added, and new items are inserted for title VII. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended to include new items such as random searches of containers, work stoppages resolution, threat assessment screening for port truck drivers, Border Patrol unit for US Virgin Islands, and Center of Excellence for Maritime Domain Awareness. Additionally, amendments are made to various sections including disclosures regarding homeland security grants, trucking security, air and marine operations of the Northern Border Air Wing, phaseout of vessels supporting oil and gas development, Coast Guard property in Portland, Maine, methamphetamine and precursor chemicals regulation, and protection of health and safety during disasters.
